items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is possible between 1:30am and 3:30am tomorrow morning, Sunday 20th February. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low-lying land between the fort and and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.50 mAODN at 2:30am, on Sunday 20th February, which is 0.68m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South-Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 20th February.

items.description: North Sea at Scarborough - Foreshore Road
items.message: This flood warning has been issued due to forecast overtopping waves and spray expected as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Consequently, flooding of property and roads and farmland is expected on the high tide between 03:30 AM and 08:30 AM, and also for the high tide between 4:00 PM and 6:30 PM on Sunday 20/02/2022. Areas most at risk are properties on Foreshore Road. Coastal conditions are expected to remain unsettled on subsequent tides and further warnings may be issued. Please put your flood plan into action and be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message on Sunday morning, or as the situation changes.

This flood warning has been issued as overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong winds. Consequently, flooding of property and roads is expected on the high tides between 3:30 AM and 8:30AM on Sunday 20/02/2022. Areas most at risk are properties at Sandside. Please put your flood plan into action and be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message on Sunday morning or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Welshbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today. We expect flooding to affect offices at the showground and Gravel Hill Lane. 
Predicted peak at Welshbridge 3.4m to 3.7m on Saturday evening 19/02/22. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast on Saturday and into Sunday. This rain will cause river levels to remain high over the next few days with the possibility of further rises on Monday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 3am on Sunday 20/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. 
Predicted Peaks:- Mythe 3.9m to 4.4m and Upper Pound 3.6m to 4.2m on Tuesday, 22/02/2022.
  We expect river levels to remain high into next week. More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated  by 10 am tomorrow morning 20/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon, seafront properties
items.message: Large and powerful waves, with associated sea spray, are expected as a result of high tides and continuing strong winds. Forecast high water is 09:30 on 20/2/22 with a level of 7.33 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and seafront properties is possible at these times, however, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade including the Marine Lake, Elton Road and The Beach. Strong winds are forecast to continue until after the high tide at 10:15 on 21/2/22, but no further flood warnings are expected. Our incident response staff are checking flood defences and we continue to closely monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday, 20/2/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force for the high tide on Saturday evening 19/02/2022, with overtopping waves and spray caused by strong winds expected between 7:00 PM and 9:30 PM. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea Village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and this alert may need to remain in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 9:00 pm on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because we have local information that water levels are remaining high and wind is still pushing water levels up on the River Thurne. High water is expected somewhere in the region of 3pm, and water levels are already high, from 2pm this afternoon, Saturday 19th February, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed and winds ease. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boatyards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. However, stormy conditions are pushing in from tomorrow and may delay water levels receding. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 20th February.

Large and powerful waves, with associated sea spray, are expected as a result of high tides and continuing strong winds. Forecast high water is 09:00 on 20/2/22 with a level of 6.51 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. The strong winds are forecast to continue until after the high tide at 09:45 on 21/2/22. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday, 20/2/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been updated due to a change in the forecast.

River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.80mAOD at 04:45 tomorrow, Sunday 20th February.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 90 cubic metres per second and is forecast to rise of the next couple of days. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday 20th February or as the situation changes.

Whilst we are not expecting any further flooding impacts on Saturday 19/02/2022, the high tide at lunch time on Sunday 20/02/2022 is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a flood warning.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. 
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by Sunday morning 20/02/2022 or if the situation changes.

Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 20/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to rise as a result of persistent (heavy) rainfall which is forecast to start around midnight and continue through much of tomorrow, Sunday 20th February. Due to the saturated conditions and thawing of any lying snow, rivers will respond readily to this rainfall and are likely to be particularly high through the afternoon and evening. 

We are monitoring the situation closely on a 24 hour basis and will issue flood warnings if properties and parts of communities are expected to flood. We currently expect river levels to peak around 4 to 5pm Sunday and remain high until overnight into Monday. Areas most at risk initially are low lying land and roads.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Consider taking appropriate steps to prepare for possible flooding, such as moving things upstairs and getting flood protection equipment ready to put in place.

This message will be updated by 07:00, 20/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels rose as a result of persistent rainfall throughout yesterday from Storm Eunice. Consequently, surface water issues and flooding of roads and farmland is possible.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Further heavy rainfall is forecast on Saturday and into Sunday. This rain will cause river levels to remain high over the next few days with the possibility of further rises on Sunday. Strong winds are expected to continue on the Bristol Channel on Sunday, coinciding with spring tides. We are expecting this to cause large waves and a tidal surge along the coast. 
First Forecast high water is 09:30 on 20/02/22 with a level of 7.34 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 21:45 on 20/02/22 with a level of 6.66 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We will update this message as the situation changes.

We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
This flood alert will remain in place until Sunday morning’s high tide, there remains a risk of wave overtopping to quays, low lying land and roads. We will update this message following Sunday morning’s high tide. 
 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
 
Rainfall forecast over the weekend is not expected to result in Main River flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
 
No further flooding is expected on Monday and Tuesday; however, stormy conditions are forecast on Wednesday, which, combined with high tides, may lead to further flooding. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.

River levels are rising due to recent rain. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. 

Predicted peaks: Bewdley 3.6 to 4m, Sunday evening 20/02/2022; Worcester 4.2 to 4.7m and Diglis 3.8 to 4.3m overnight Sunday, 20/02/22. Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9 to 6.4m and Saxons Lode 4.3 to 4.7m on Tuesday, 22/02/2022. 

More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday, 20/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Sunday’s tides will be lower than recent days, but still accompanied by strong Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The unsettled weather increases tide table values by 0.15 m. The total forecast tide Sunday morning at 01:30 on 20/02/2022 is 5.86 metres Chart Datum (2.81 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Further minor flood impacts are expected until Monday, as strong winds and large waves are forecast to continue. Conditions should improve from Tuesday 22/02/2022. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest to reduce flood risk to property. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 20/02/2022

We are issuing this message as a precaution. Storm Eunice and subsequent large waves have moved some shingle from the beaches between Bracklesham and Medmerry. However, both tides Sunday are forecast to be lower than recent days, and with smaller waves. At 01:45 on 20/02/2022 strong Force 6 Westerly winds increases tide table values by 0.05 m. The total forecast tide is 4.83 metres Chart Datum (2.09 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 2 hours either side of high water, it is possible a small amount of water could flow over the beach crest and collect in the pools and fields near Medmerry Park Holiday Village, Bracklesham. A small amount of wave generated and wind blown spray could also affect beach top properties at the end of West Sands Lane and Medmerry. Minor flood impacts could continue until Monday, while strong winds and large waves remain. Conditions should improve Tuesday 22/02/2022. Our asset inspectors will assess the beach condition on Sunday. Stormy seas are dangerous, please take care if visiting the beach. We will update this message by 20:00 on 20/02/2022

Sunday’s tides will be lower than recent days, but still accompanied by strong Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The unsettled weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide Sunday morning at 01:15 on 20/02/2022 is 6.99 metres Chart Datum (3.47 mAOD) at Newhaven. For 2 hours either side of high water, a small amount of spray overtopping will affect footpaths, sea front parking and the road at Marine Parade and the Esplanade. Further similarly minor flood impacts are expected Monday, as strong winds and large waves are forecast to continue. Conditions should improve from Tuesday 22/02/2022. We continue to monitor the forecast. At low tide we will check and work to maintain the condition of the shingle beach which helps to protect the town from flooding. Avoid walking, parking and driving along Seaford Sea Front at high tide. Spray and water will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. We will update this message by 10:00 on 20/02/2022

Sunday’s tides will be lower than recent days, but still accompanied by strong Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The unsettled weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide Sunday morning at 01:15 on 20/02/2022 is 7.24 metres Chart Datum (3.59 mAOD) at Eastbourne. For 2 hours either side of high water, beach top properties at Pevensey Bay will be affected by spray caused by the large waves, and the road at Herbrand Walk may flood. Further similarly minor flood impacts are expected Monday, as strong winds and large waves are forecast to continue. Conditions should improve from Tuesday 22/02/2022. We continue to monitor the forecast. To protect property from flooding, at low tide, Pevensey Coastal Defence Ltd will maintain the condition of the shingle beach. Avoid Pevensey beach at high tide. Spray and waves will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. As a precaution, plan driving routes to avoid Herbrand Walk. We will update this message by 10:00 on 20/02/2022

A predicted peak at Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9 to 6.4m is expected on Tuesday, 22/02/22. 
More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.

River levels are expected to rise as a result of persistent (heavy) rainfall which is forecast to start around midnight and continue through much of tomorrow, Sunday 20th February. We are monitoring the situation closely on a 24 hour basis and will issue flood warnings if properties and parts of communities are expected to flood. We currently expect an initial peak in river levels at Keighley around 9am Sunday, with another peak possible later in the afternoon. Areas most at risk initially are low lying land and roads.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated at 07:45, 20/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Strong winds, Gale Force at times, are set to continue until Tuesday 22/02/2022, which will generate large waves this weekend. However, conditions will still be slightly calmer than during Storm Eunice. Sunday’s early morning tide at 01:30 on 20/02/2022 at Littlehampton is forecast to be over half a metre lower than on Friday 18/02/2022. Minor flood impacts caused by high water levels or wave generated and wind blown spray will continue, but with much smaller volumes and much less likely to affect properties. Please continue to take care on exposed coastlines in the unsettled conditions. We have staff inspecting flood defence assets along the Sussex coastline and will continue to monitor the weather forecasts. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.

Coastal conditions are easing following yesterday’s Storm EUNICE.  There is no longer a threat of flooding although winds remain strong and some tidal surge continues.  The tide peak overnight is forecast to be 3.76m above Ordnance Datum with Force 5 South Westerly winds.  Winds tomorrow, 20th February daytime, will increase to Force 8 although tide levels continue to reduce.  Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  Our incident staff are checking defences and continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Cumbrian coastline from Silloth to St Bees including Maryport, Flimby, Workington and Whitehaven
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
The high tide on Sunday afternoon (20/02/2022) is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further flood alert.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Strong winds, Gale Force at times, are set to continue until Tuesday 22/02/2022, which will generate large waves this weekend. However, conditions will still be slightly calmer than during Storm Eunice. Sunday’s early morning tide at 01:45 on 20/02/2022 at Chichester Harbour is forecast to be over half a metre lower than Friday 18/02/2022. Minor flood impacts caused by high water levels, or wave generated and wind blown spray, will continue, but with much smaller volumes. This will be much less likely to affect properties. Flood impacts are no longer expected to affect Bosham High Street. Please continue to take care on exposed coastlines in the unsettled conditions. We have staff inspecting flood defence assets along the Sussex coastline and will continue to monitor the weather forecasts. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message:
Although river levels have now fallen, please be aware levels are likely to rise again due to further heavy and persistent rainfall throughout Sunday, 20/02/2022, and into Monday, 21/02/2022. 
Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if necessary, over the next few days.
